addressleaf.section:
To my very lovinge friende M
r
Thomas Bodleigh Esq
r
, Counseler for her M
tie
in
e Counsel of state of
e United Provinces in
e Low Contreis at
e Hage/

From S
r
Frauncis Walsingham the 25 of Julye 1589

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 28 Julye To M
r
Bodly
M
r
Bodleigh
S
r
, In answear to yo
r
letters w
ch
I received,
e one
of
e 26 of
e last moneth,
e other of
e 9 of this
instant July, yow shall understand,
t
I doe not much
marveile at
e sharpenes and hard bent of
Barnevelt
against her
M
tie
,
and this motion, and
e whot course
he holdeth in all consultations and actions touchinge
them: for
t
in sondry conferences of
e
LL.
had w
th
e
Deputies here, there have bin hard speaches lett fall of
him, and of his harshe humors: w
ch
it may be the
Deputies advertised over, ether in respect of good will
t
some of them in particuler doe beare him, or to sharpen
him more in his humor, therby the soner to make him
to r
u
ne him self out of breath, and to become odious
amongest them. And if I be not deceived by some
other privat advise, w
ch
I have from thence, I purcei-
ve it wil so fall out in
e ende, and
t
before it be longe,
for I am advertised,
t
his doinges are not greatly liked,
or rather much misliked, of
e best and most, and
t
he is likely to weare him selfe out of conceipt before it be
longe, if he change not e course of his humors. for
it is reported,
t
he
setteth to draw a line
t
is both unlikely
ever to be broght to passe, and
t
in it self, can not
but tourne to
e ruine rather of those contreis, then any
good.
As for direction for yo
r
self, there can as yet be no better
given, then yow have alredy receaved, for
t
all cer-
taintie therein wil depend uppon such Conference as
by more ample C
o
mission given to these Deputies
wilbe had w
th
them, or w
th
such other as
e states
shall thinke good to sende over. W
ch
matter yow shall
doe well to hasten, and so their LL. pleasure is yow
shold procure w
th
all instancie yow c
a
: who like very
well
fol.52v
well of yo
r
procedinge w
th
e
states
accordinge to
e direc-
tion yow formerly received from them in
t
behalf.
Amongest them yow may not forgett to acknowledge yo
r
self much bound and beholdinge to
e
L. Treasorer
, who
hath of times delivered good wordes to her M
tie
of
yo
r
painefull travail and advised dealinge in the
charge c
o
mitted to yow. Yow shall doe well in
t
respect, to wright oftener to his L. wherein as yow shall
doe him satisfaction, so it can not but tourne to yo
r
good.
Were it not
t
e matter of sendinge other C
o
missioners
hither, or more ample C
o
mission to these, had bin
so farre forth proceded in as it is, both her M
tie
and
e LL.
coold have better liked to have had
e Conference and
meetinge of C
o
missioners there, beinge of opinion,
t
e Conference wold have bin w
th
more spede ended there
then it wilbe here. But seing it is as it is,
e course is not
to be altered, but their dispatche to be hastened, w
ch
is eftso-
nes rec
o
mended to yo
r
charge and care.
Their LL. were in a good way by conference w
th
e Deputies, to
have taken s
o
me reasonable course for
e satisfaction of
e
L. Willughby
. W
ch
e said Deputies had in part promi-
sed, but
e cominge forth of his L. apologie, brake of that
purpose.
This morninge we received newes out of
France
of
e murder
of
e
K
by a Jacopin, and
t
e Nobilitie & Capteines
of
e armie, gave their othe to
e
K of Navarre,
[.]
[.] to be loyall and trew unto him, and not to forsake him,
but to seke by all meanes
e revenge of so horrible an owt-
rage c
o
mitted uppon
e parson of
e K.
And so I leave yow
to God. from
e Court at Nonesuch
e
28
of July
1589
.
Yo
r
very lovinge freinde Francis Walsyngham
